messageBody:
Hey,

Sorry for my /much/ slower reply.
I've looked at JUnitCore, and it seems like I either need to copy code
from it (if I intend to simply create the Runner by myself, provide it
with a RunNotifier I create and execute it) or hack up my own Runner
that exposes the pleaseStop() method and pass it to JUnitCore.
Both of these ways don't seem optimal.
Am I missing a better option?

Thanks,
Aviv.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Aviv,
>
> Sorry for the slow reply. To get a reference to RunNotifier, you'll
> need to bypass JUnitCore and get straight to the Runner in your custom
> main. Take a look at JUnitCore.run(Runner) and let me know if that's
> helpful.
>
> I assume your extension kept a persistent list of failed tests
> somehow. If so, you can use that in a Filter, comparing the names of
> the failed tests to each method to decide which to run.
>
> Sounds like interesting work--let me know how it goes. Thanks,
>
> David Saff
>
> On 7/29/07, aviv_benyosef <aviv.by@...> wrote:
> > Heya.
> > In my workplace we've had for quite some time a neat class that simply
> > ran one of JUnit's runners and added some nice functionality - like
> > catching SIGINT from the user and then telling JUnit to stop after the
> > current test finishes.
> >
> > Now we're looking into making it work with JUnit4, and I see no nice
> > way of doing it from outside the tests. I saw a thread here that
> > showed a usage of RunNotifier.pleaseStop(), but I couldn't find a way
> > to get a RunNotifier outside of a runner.
> > Is there a way?
> >
> > Also, it has a nice feature of resuming the last failed test. How can
> > this be done in JUnit4?
> >
> >
> > Thanks a lot,
> > Aviv.
